Renderer Class Reference

#include <Renderer.h>

List of all members.

Detailed Description

This class provides a more object-oriented friendly interface to OpenGL It has defaults which serve to the the user do a quick & dirty program to test the rendering of the objects in the Object class.

The idea is to provide enough methods to allow you to customize any aspect of rendering as you would in openGL/glut, but also allow you to just use the defaults for a quick hack. Note that this is not really a proper "Object" as everything is public. Access variables and methods you are told not to call at your own risk! Everything is public done to allow as little weirdness to come between the call to a method and calls to the underlying openGL/glut functions as possible, and also to allow the user write methods that overrided existing glut handlers.

The following methods are set as glut handlers and work as described by default. You may be able to override some of them to provide your own glut handlers:
reshape() : works as per the tutorials in the OpenGL red book No real need to overridde this seen yet handler passed to the glutReshapeFunc.
display() : draws the object list to the screen.
there most likely will never be provided a way to override this method. handler passed to the glutDisplayFunc.
look() : when in look mode handles mouse motion to move the camera. Note the default keyboard key to toggle in and out of look mode is 'Z'. Set as the handler for the glutPassiveMotionFunc() method
mouse() : current default just calls glutPostRedisplay and returns. Set as the handler for the glutMouseFunc. When object selection is ironed out, may handle selecting and moving selectable objects by default.
keyboard(): set as the default handler for the glutKeyboardFunc. Its default for handling keyboard behavior is as follows:
'q''Q': moves the camera down
'e''E': moves the camera up
's''S': moves the camera backward
'w''W': moves the camera forward
'd''D': moves the camera right
'a''A': moves the camera left
't''T': adjusts the theta for the camera
'i' : moves the camera 0.5 in the direction of the cameras y-axis
'k' : moves the camera -0.5 in the direction of the cameras y-axis
'j' : moves the camera 0.5 in the direction of the cameras x-axis
'l' : moves the camera -0.5 in the direction of the cameras x-axis
'u' : moves the camera 0.5 in the direction of the cameras z-axis
'o' : moves the camera -0.5 in the direction of the cameras z-axis
'z' : toggles in and out of look mode. If your not in look mode, your in select mode

As will all other classes by me in evolve, the printDebug argument turns on debugging messages.
The doNotify method turns on notifications messages
Enjoy!

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Renderer::Renderer (   ) 
 

Default contructor.

Sets the variables to a lot of values you probably don't want. Use other methods to change them to what you do want
